Several effective measures including restricting travel from China, controlling the distribution of masks, extensive investigation of COVID-19 spread, and at once daily press conference by government to inform and educate people were aggressively conducted in Taiwan. Coronavirus disease 2019; Disease incidence; Daily cumulative index; Mortality; Country healthcare resources

Since the first reported case of coronavirus disease 2019 in Wuhan, China at the end of 2019, COVID-19 has rapidly spread throughout China and also involved many other countries in spite of the global effort to prevent its spread. 1-4 According to the report of World Health Organization (WHO), COVID-19 has affected 84,503 patients in 57 countries/territories and caused 2,924 deaths by February 29, 2020, of which approximately 92.9% of cases and 97.1% of deaths are in China. 1 Among these 57 countries/territories, the cases reported in 20 countries/territories were attributed to local transmission of COVID-19, while those in 37 countries/regions were imported cases. However, the incidence and mortality of COVID-19 varied in different countries//territories. The incidence ranged from 61.4 per 1,000,000 people in Republic of Korea to 0.0002 per 1,000,000 people in India (Table 1) .

To date, five regions had COVID-19 cases, including Asia, Eastern mediterranean, Europe, America, and Africa. Of course, the highest incidence of COVID-19 was reported in Asia (n = 82,988), followed by Europe (n = 1,119), Eastern mediterranean region (n = 510), America (n = 79), and African (n =2) ( Figure 1 ). Within the last week of February, the number of new cases was highest in Asia (n = 5,019), followed by European (n = 998) and Eastern mediterranean region (n = 467). The overall mortality rate was highest in Eastern mediterranean region (6.7%, n = 34), followed by Asia (3.4%, n = 2,861) and Europe (2.1%, n = 23%). In contrast, there was no death in America and African as of February 29, 2020.

The DCI was greatest in China (1320.85 per day), followed by Republic of Korea (78.78 per day), Iran (43.11 per day), Italy (30.62 per day), Bahrain (9.5 per day), Kuwait (9 per day), and Japan (5.11 per day). The DCI in other countries/SARs was less than 4 per day.
body_text.section: Disease incidence, mortality rates, and daily cumulative index of COVID-19 by country

body_text.text: China has the highest number of COVID-19 cases in the world (n = 79,251), and the incidence was 55.1 per 1,000,000 people. Among these cases, 2,835 patients died, and the overall mortality was 3.6%. Despite the increasing trend of daily new cases in the early stage, the trend of daily new case seemed to decline with time since late February 2020. Moreover, the number of daily new cases in China was lesser than that outside of China since February 26, 2020. According to the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention, 5 81% of the patients with COVID-19 had a mild case, and 87% were aged 30-79 years. In addition, 3.8% of those with COVID-19 were health care personnel. The case-fatality rate was higher in those with critical cases (49%), and patients aged ≥80 years (14.8%). 5

Until the end of February, 705 of the 3,700 passengers of the Diamond Princess cruise ship had confirmed COVID-19 and 6 died, with a mortality rate of 0.9%. The basic reproduction rate (R 0 ) was initially four times higher on-board than the R 0 in Wuhan.

However, the implementation of isolation and quarantine procedures helped prevent the spread of COVID-19 in more than 2,000 passengers and lowered the R 0 to 1.78. 6 Although the experience of this cruise ship provided a good model for understanding the behavior of COVID-19 spread, the spread of disease could have been prevented if all passengers and crew were evacuated early.

In addition to China, four countries (Republic of Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran) had ≥100 COVID-19 cases. Besides Japan, which showed slowly increasing cases, other three countries had a rapid increase in COVID-19 incidence since late February ( Figure 2 ). Among these four countries, Iran had the highest mortality (n = 34), with a mortality rate of 8.7%. Even though these countries had more COVID-19 cases than other sites except China, the number of cases seemed to increase with time.
body_text.section: Countries/territories with more than 100 cumulative cases

body_text.text: Five countries/territories had 50-99 cumulative cases, including Hong Kong SAR, Singapore, United States, Germany, and France. Although the first COVID-19 case reported in these five sites occurred in late January 2020, the number of cases continued to increase at the end of February ( Figure 2B ). Seven countries had 20-49 cumulative cases, including Taiwan, Australia, Malaysia, United Kingdom, Spain, Bahrain, and Kuwait. Except the five countries whose first cases were reported in late January 2020, the 1 st COVID-19 cases in Bahrain and Kuwait were reported on February 25 and February 29, 2020, respectively ( Figure 2C ). Six countries/territories had 10-19 cumulative cases, including Switzerland, United Arab Emirates, Macau SAR, Sweden, Vietnam, and Canada. Except Switzerland, all the other five reported the first cases before February ( Figure 2D ). In addition, no new cases were reported in Macau SAR, and Vietnam for 25 and 16 days, respectively.

Ten of fifty-seven countries/regions had stable numbers of COVID-19 cases for ≥15 days, including Nepal, Cambodia, Sri Lanka, Russian Federation, India, Macau SAR, Philippines, Belgium, Vietnam, and Egypt. The days since last reported case was largest for Nepal (n = 47), followed by Cambodia (n = 33), and Sri Lanka (n = 33). Except Vietnam and Macau SAR (which had 16 and 10 COVID-19 cases, respectively), the other eight countries had a total of 3 cases. In addition to the Philippines, none of them reported of any COVID-19-related deaths.
body_text.section: Countries/territories with stable number of COVID-19 cases

body_text.text: Taiwan is a country geographically near China and has a close contact with China, which makes it more susceptible to COVID-19 spread. To manage this challenge, infection control measures including prohibiting travel from China, controlling the distribution of mask, extensive investigation of COVID-19 spread, and at once daily press conference to inform and educate people by government were aggressively conducted in Taiwan ( Figure 3A ).
Under these interventions, Taiwan has a total of 39 cases with a DCI of 1 case per day, which was much lower than that of the nearby countries, such as Republic of Korea and Japan

Based on the earlier experience in China, Ji et al. found a significant correlation between mortality and healthcare resource availability (r = 0.61). 8 We wonder whether the association between mortality and healthcare burden can be demonstrated outside of China and whether there are other confounding factors, such as the level of healthcare. Therefore, we used two indexes to represent the level of healthcare: Health Care Index (HCI), 9 and Healthcare Access and Quality Index (HAQI). 10 HCI is based on surveys from visitors of one open website and questions for these surveys are similar to many similar scientific and government surveys. 9 HAQI uses 32 scaled cause values, providing an overall score of 0-100 of personal health-care access and quality by location over time. 10 Firstly, we found that mortality rate, incidence, and death per 1000,000 people were correlated with DCI (Spearman's rank-order correlation, all p < 0.05) ( Figure 4A ), and this association was more prominent in countries with local transmission ( Table 2 ). This finding is consistent with Ji et al.'s findings 7 and suggests that rapidly increasing cases in a short time can result in more cases and even more deaths. Secondly, the incidence was associated with life expectancy (r = 0.613, p < 0.001).
body_text.section: Association between mortality and disease incidence

body_text.text: This could be because countries with more older adults were more likely to acquire COVID-19. Finally, the incidence was found to be correlated with both HAQI (r = 0.516, p < 0.001) and HCI (r = 0.345, p < 0.001), but mortality and death were not associated with the level of healthcare ( Figure 4B and 4C ). This finding may be explained by the fact that countries with more advanced healthcare systems have better diagnostic ability to identify more cases. By contrast, no death cases were reported in most countries; thus, no significant correlation could be found. However, further study is warranted to clarify these findings.
body_text.section: Association between mortality and disease incidence

body_text.text: Between December 31, 2019 and February 29, 2020, COVID-19 has affected more than 80,000 patients in 57 countries/territories and caused 2,924 deaths in nine countries. Although China had higher morbidity and mortality rates than other sites, the number of daily new cases was lesser in China than that outside of China since February 26, 2020. Seven countries had a DCI of more than 5 cases per day, but the DCI of other 50 countries/territories was less than 4 cases per day. The incidence and mortality rates were correlated with DCI, especially in countries with local transmission. Overall, this preliminary report shows us the initial epidemiological findings of COVID-19, but continuous monitor of patients with this disease is still warranted. implementation of primary control measures in Taiwan from January 21 to February 29, 2020.

Among the 39 patients, 18 acquired the COVID-19 infection outsideTaiwan, of whom three of them were Chinese visitors from China, while the other 21 developed the infection in Taiwan (http://nidss.cdc.gov.tw/ch/SingleDisease.aspx?dc=1&dt=5&disease=19CoV). Four familial cluster transmissions and one nosocomial transmission were reported. To date, 11 patients were discharged (Figure 3C). Several important actions and responses conducted by the National Health Command Center of Taiwan, including border control, resource reallocation, case identification (using new data and technology), quarantine of suspicious cases using the big data analytics, reassurance and education of the public, mask control and of hand hygiene, and formulation of policies toward schools and childcare, have so far successfully alleviated the crisis and contained the epidemic inTaiwan. 7
